This study is part of a series on why nations rise and fall, succeed or fail in rivalries, and enjoy stability or descend into chaos.
Learn more: https://t.co/RCkrEQ3E0s
Download the full report here: https://t.co/EwiS5v8HKo

However, there *is* cause for optimism.
Although many powerful barriers stand in the way, the U.S. has all the preconditions for a potential agenda of anticipatory renewal.
It has tremendous residual strengths and a proven capacity for resilience and renewal.

In particular, the combination of these three factors poses a major threat:
🔸 a ruined information environment 🔸 political polarization and fragmentation 🔸 evidence that institutions of governance are seizing up and losing public confidence.

There’s no emerging consensus on the barriers to renewal that demand urgent action. And the essential problem is seen in starkly different terms by different segments of society and groups of political leaders.
Right now, the U.S. is not yet demonstrating widespread shared recognition of societal challenges or the determination to reform.

Several common factors appear to distinguish cases of successful anticipatory renewal from failures. These include a sense of national solidarity, resources to deploy reforms, and a clear understanding of the problems. https://t.co/oo48d1VWy3

The U.S. may be entering a period requiring anticipatory national renewal.
In a few cases, societies identified challenges to their competitive position and undertook social, political, and economic reforms to sustain their power. The U.S. seems to have arrived at such a moment.

Recovery from significant long-term national decline is rare and difficult to detect in the historical record.
When great powers have slid from a position of preeminence because of domestic factors, they have seldom reversed this trend.
Two men charged over felling of Sycamore gap tree https://t.co/zgbi0R0CuP

In some historical cases, great powers have sensed a negative trajectory and taken steps to prevent more serious decline. The authors call this "anticipatory national renewal."
The report explores historical cases of anticipatory renewal and offers lessons for the U.S. today...
Iran: Death sentence commuted for oil billionaire https://t.co/rPHoit8XCg

It's also threatened from outside, in terms of
🔸 a rising direct challenge from China 🔸 declining deference to U.S. power from dozens of developing nations.
Left unchecked, these trends will accelerate the relative decline in U.S. standing.

@MMazarr and coauthors explain that America's competitive position is currently threatened from within, in terms of
🔸 slowing productivity growth 🔸 an aging population 🔸 political polarization 🔸 an increasingly corrupted information environment.

History is full of great powers that hit a peak of competitive power and then stagnate and eventually decline. Few nations in that position can renew their standing.
New RAND research finds that the United States faces precisely this challenge. 🧵 https://t.co/EwiS5v8HKo
